title: Session 5: Circular Cities & Regions - Key Takeaways
content:
ğŸ™ï¸ From Place to Planet: Building Circular Futures

Session 5 of #NordicCircularSummit brought together leaders from Riga, Cesis, Oslo, and Greenland to explore place-based circular city development.

ğŸ”‘ THREE CRITICAL PATTERNS:

1ï¸âƒ£ **RETROFIT FIRST = ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY**
â€¢ London: regulatory requirement (2020) completely changed the scene
â€¢ Oslo: transformations are "best practices in real estate development"
â€¢ Greenland Disko Bay: renovation = ~50% cost of new construction
â€¢ Structural reuse = massive CO2 savings (especially concrete)

2ï¸âƒ£ **CIRCULAR PROCUREMENT = LEVERAGE POINT**
â€¢ Riga: circular construction guidelines in all procurement
â€¢ Riga: material banks for departments to share assets
â€¢ Cesis: organic food procurement for schools/kindergartens
â€¢ "The procurement muscle" shapes markets, not just purchases

3ï¸âƒ£ **TRUST + COMMUNITY = FOUNDATION**
â€¢ Greenland: no mandatory legislation, collective agreement instead
â€¢ Cesis: memorandum of goodwill with 13 institutions (1 year to craft)
â€¢ Riga: 108 speakers, 34 sessions at first Circular Economy Forum

ğŸ’¬ THE QUOTE:
"For the most important thing you have to build when you build places is trust. If you don't have trust, you don't manage to create any good place."
â€” Einar Kleppe Holthe, Natural State, Norway

title: Riga: From Capital City to Circular Economy Lab
content:
ğŸ‡±ğŸ‡» RIGA: One of 100 EU Climate Neutral Cities

How Latvia's capital became a circular economy lab:

ğŸ† **THE ACHIEVEMENT:**
EU Mission Label - one of 100 climate neutral and smart cities

ğŸ¯ **THE VISION:**
"A modern driving force for circular economy innovations, a circular economy lab within the country, and a source of inspiration for other cities."
â€” TÄlis Linkaits, Riga Energy Agency

ğŸ“‹ **THREE WORK DIRECTIONS:**

1ï¸âƒ£ **Citizen Engagement**
"Urban environments have forgotten circular practices."
â†’ Get back to basics: household separation, daily reuse
â†’ School competitions (2nd year)
â†’ Design university students compete for solutions

2ï¸âƒ£ **Municipality Resources**
â†’ Circular construction guidelines (used in procurement)
â†’ Material banks: departments share assets/inventory
â†’ Pre-studies before transformations using circular principles

3ï¸âƒ£ **Circular Businesses**
Not fundingâ€”but moderating, stimulating, influencing
â†’ Networking and community building
â†’ Gather like-minded businesses for synergies

ğŸ—ï¸ **PRACTICAL EXAMPLES:**

**Urban Resource Center:**
â€¢ Repair facility + community center
â€¢ Circular design from beginning
â€¢ Added to EU database for good circular procurement practices
â€¢ Lectures, activities, repair guidance

**Library Garden:**
â€¢ Unique outdoor area using circularity principles
â€¢ People gather for concerts, discussions, cultural activities
â€¢ Opening spring 2025

**Real Estate Transformation:**
â€¢ Pre-study: transform property to social care house
â€¢ Use all circularity principles + available materials within building
â€¢ Subsequent procurement based on circular criteria

ğŸ¤ **LATVIAN CIRCULAR ECONOMY FORUM:**
"So popular we had to cut participants, but still:
â€¢ 108 speakers
â€¢ 34 thematic sessions
â€¢ Business cases, universities, NGOs, public sector
â€¢ People so willing to tell their stories"

ğŸ’° **FUNDING MODEL:**
"We do basically not from public funding, but by attracting different EU funds and different sponsors and grants."

ğŸ”‘ **THE INSIGHT:**
Riga acts as strategic brokerâ€”identifying opportunities, assembling resources, convening stakeholders.

Not controller. Catalyst.

title: Cesis: The First Bioregion in the Baltic States
content:
ğŸŒ² THE FIRST BALTIC BIOREGION: Cesis, Latvia

"We cannot excel in every area being all alone. By working together, small regions can achieve more than they could ever do in isolation."
â€” Inese Suija-Markova, Deputy Mayor of Cesis & Regional Mayor of Vidzeme

ğŸ“ **CONTEXT:**
â€¢ 90 km northeast of Riga
â€¢ Vidzeme region: beautiful landscape, forests, meadows, clean air
â€¢ Deep sense of community, strong cultural traditions
â€¢ But: sparse population, aging demographic, limited economic scale

ğŸ’¡ **THE SOLUTION: BIOREGION**

October 2023: Four municipalities + farmers + NGOs + entrepreneurs + researchers + residents

**What is a bioregion?**
"NOT an administrative unit. A geographic and cultural space where public authorities, farmers, tourism operators, businesses and citizens AGREE to manage local resources sustainably based on ecological principles and shared responsibility."

In essence: **A SOCIAL CONTRACT.**

ğŸ“œ **MEMORANDUM OF GOODWILL:**
â€¢ Crafted over ONE YEAR
â€¢ Every word agreed by stakeholders
â€¢ 13 institutions: public, private, NGO, academic
â€¢ Public commitment to create cleaner, healthier, circular region
â€¢ 6 principles for working together
â€¢ 8 working directions

ğŸ¯ **EIGHT PRIORITY AREAS:**
1. Healthy, organic food access
2. Short food supply chains
3. Natural capital management (ecosystem services)
4. Waste reduction
5. Energy efficiency & renewables
6. Sustainability education
7. Authentic, nature-friendly tourism
8. (Implementation details)

âœ… **THREE PRACTICAL EXAMPLES:**

**1. Organic Food in Schools/Kindergartens**
â€¢ Transform procurement system
â€¢ Local, organic ingredients replace anonymous supply chains
â€¢ First organically certified school kitchen in Latvia (in progress)
â€¢ Reduced emissions + healthier food + local economic value

**2. Circular Economy Center at Landfill**
â€¢ Different concept: waste as resource
â€¢ Develop new products from waste streams
â€¢ Transformation, not just disposal

**3. Financial Instruments + LEADER Integration**
â€¢ Municipal grants for circular businesses
â€¢ Integrated bioregion principles into LEADER program (EU rural funding)
â€¢ Mainstreamed into funding strategies = "great success"

ğŸŒ **THE PHILOSOPHY:**
"A strategic alliance based on shared values and really the aim to be in touch with the nature, to live in accordance with the nature, to respect the environment where we live."

ğŸ”‘ **KEY LESSON:**
Rural challenges (population, scale, resources) become innovation drivers.

Cooperation > competition.
Place-based > one-size-fits-all.
Voluntary agreement > top-down mandate.

This is circular economy at its most integrated.

title: Greenland's Trust-Based Strategy: No Legislation Required
content:
ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡± GREENLAND: Trust Over Legislation

Most countries mandate sustainability through regulation.

Greenland chose a different path.

ğŸ“‹ **NATIONAL SUSTAINABILITY STRATEGY (2024):**
For construction and civil engineering sector.

But here's what makes it unique:

ğŸ’¬ **THE CORE DECISION:**
"We must succeed together. This also includes that we're not gonna, at least for now, put in some legislation concerning sustainability. We should be able to do this together and agree on all of those things."
â€” Embla KristjÃ¡nsdÃ³ttir, Ministry for Housing, Infrastructure and Outer Districts

**WHY THIS WORKS:**
â€¢ Small industry
â€¢ Strong sense of community
â€¢ Lot of trust between all working in industry
â€¢ Geographic, climatic, logistical uniqueness

ğŸ¯ **THE APPROACH:**
Holistic approach to sustainability across entire sector.

Not top-down mandates.
Collective agreement enabled by community trust.

**THREE GUIDING PRINCIPLES:**
1. Sustainability = active element in ALL government construction projects
2. Create healthy, high-quality buildings for future generations
3. Shared understanding of sustainability across the sector

**SIX GOALS** (intentionally limited):
"It's not many goals, which is also our purpose. It should be goals that we can actually meet."

**SEVEN CONCRETE INITIATIVES:**
â€¢ Principles for sustainability
â€¢ Art & architecture prioritization
â€¢ National DGNB system development
â€¢ Shared LCA methodology
â€¢ Council for Sustainability establishment
â€¢ CO2 emissions action plan
â€¢ (Monitoring/communication)

ğŸ—ï¸ **DGNB APPROACH:**
"The government is not gonna do certified projects. We're gonna go with the DGNB standard, but we're not gonna get the certification. It doesn't really give anything of value to us."

Use standard = yes.
Bureaucratic certification = no.

But it needs to exist for private projects.

ğŸ“Š **THE CHALLENGE:**
"We don't have any data at the moment."

Council meetings focus on: how do we get to CO2 action plan without baseline data?

Answer: Start somewhere. Build baseline during implementation.

ğŸ” **WHAT THIS DEMONSTRATES:**

âœ… Trust can replace (or supplement) mandatory legislation
âœ… Small groups with strong relationships move faster
âœ… Social contracts work where community is strong
âœ… Vision can be ambitious even with limited resources
âœ… Honesty about challenges (no data) builds credibility
âœ… Goals should be achievable, not overwhelming

ğŸ’¡ **THE INSIGHT:**
Regulation is ONE tool for sustainability.

But in the right context, with the right culture:

Trust + collective agreement + shared framework = powerful alternative.

ğŸŒ **TRANSFERABLE LESSONS:**
â€¢ Start with dialogue before regulation
â€¢ Leverage existing community trust
â€¢ Be honest about data limitations
â€¢ Set achievable goals
â€¢ Create forums for cooperation (e.g., Council for Sustainability)
â€¢ Adapt international standards to local context

"The needs of the present must be met without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs."
â€” Greenland National Strategy vision

This is intergenerational trust made policy.

title: Place Economy Principles
content:
ğŸŒ PLACE ECONOMY PRINCIPLES ğŸŒ
From Session 5 at #NordicCircularSummit in Nuuk, Greenland

ğŸ’¬ "The language of this structure is economy, is numbers. That is why you need to learn how to speak economic, and for instance, circular economic."
â€” Einar Kleppe Holthe, Natural State, Norway

ğŸ”‘ KEY PRINCIPLES:

ğŸ“ **PLACE MATTERS**
"The life of placeâ€”city life, village life, neighborhood lifeâ€”is also the life of our planet, is where you create or you have the activity."

ğŸ”º **TRIANGULATE FOR CLARITY**
Place + Approach + Topic = Concrete Value Proposition

Example:
â€¢ Place: Oslo
â€¢ Approach: Circular economy
â€¢ Topic: Construction
= Oslo circular building transformation projects

ğŸ’° **ECONOMIC CONSEQUENCE OF AWARENESS**
Understanding effect and cause of our systems â†’ sustainable value creation principles â†’ sustainability economies as languages

ğŸŒ **FOUR VALUE TYPES (NOT JUST ONE)**
âœ… Nature value

âœ… Societal value
âœ… Market value

ğŸ“Š **THE DYNAMICS:**
â€¢ Dynamics of place = dynamics of values

title: Nordic LCA Revolution
content:
ğŸ“Š NORDIC LCA REVOLUTION ğŸ“Š
Life Cycle Assessment requirements spreading globally

ğŸŒ **WHAT IS LCA?**
Calculating climate impact across ALL phases:
â€¢ Raw material extraction
â€¢ Processing
â€¢ Transport
â€¢ Construction
â€¢ Use
â€¢ End of life

Every step. Every emission. Every building.

âš¡ **THE TIMELINE:**

ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª **SWEDEN** - First to mandate by law
When you build new â†’ must calculate

ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡´ **NORWAY** - Shortly after
Same requirement

ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡° **DENMARK 2023** - Went further
Must calculate + LIMIT VALUES
(Maximum CO2 per square meter)

ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¸ **ICELAND September 2024** - Joined
Calculation now required

ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡® **FINLAND 2026** - Coming soon
Limit values set

ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º **EU 2028** - Buildings >1,000 sqm
Must calculate

ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º **EU 2030** - All countries
Must plan toward 2050 limits

ğŸ”¥ **THE GAME-CHANGER:**

ğŸ’¬ "What about reused products? What should they calculate for?"

Answer from Nordic countries:
**SET TO ZERO** âš¡

Not the real number (transport/processing has emissions).

But: political push.

âœ… **WHY THIS MATTERS:**

1. **Incentive structure**
   Reused products = zero or near-zero in calculations
   = Massive advantage over virgin materials

2. **Harmonization**
   Nordic countries worked together
   Could have been much more different
   Now: similar (not identical) regulations

3. **Global spread**
   This trend is spreading worldwide
   First movers = competitive advantage

ğŸ—ï¸ **IMPLICATIONS FOR CONSTRUCTION:**

ğŸŸ¢ **ADVANTAGE:**
â€¢ Local/regional production
â€¢ Short supply chains
â€¢ Direct supplier relationships
â€¢ In-house manufacturing
â€¢ Reuse and renovation focus

ğŸ”´ **CHALLENGE:**
â€¢ Long global supply chains
â€¢ Multi-tier suppliers
â€¢ Opaque processes
â€¢ Virgin material dependence
â€¢ Demolition-first mindset

ğŸ’¡ **THE INSIGHT:**

"Not having control over your supply chain is expensive. Once you have control, it's easier to cost cut."
â€” Gisle Mariani Mardal (from Session 4)

LCA compliance = competitive advantage for transparent companies.

ğŸ“š **LEARN MORE:**

Nordic Sustainable Construction
â†’ Toolbox for Future-Proofed Construction
â†’ Educational program in 6 Nordic languages + English
â†’ Freely available online

Nordic Climate Forum for Construction
â†’ Annual gathering
â†’ Policy measures catalogue
â†’ Recordings available

ğŸ¯ **2030 VISION:**

"Within five years, the Nordic countries have this vision of being the most sustainable and integrated region in the world."
â€” Helle Redder Momsen

LCA requirements = foundation for that vision.

Is your organization ready?

title: Arctic Construction Wisdom
content:
ğŸ”ï¸ ARCTIC CONSTRUCTION WISDOM ğŸ”ï¸
Traditional knowledge meets modern circular economy

ğŸ‘¤ **INOORAQ BRANDT**
General Manager, Buildings
RambÃ¸ll GrÃ¸nland A/S, Greenland

From #NordicCircularSummit Session 5

ğŸ’¬ **"AS A WIC, WE CAN USE ALMOST ANYTHING"**

"We essentially come from a place where:

How can I construct any piece of equipment or whatever in a ROBUST way that I ensure that I'm also able to maintain?

Because our survival essentially depends on it."

â° **OLD TIME vs. NEW TIME**

"The words that come to mind when people describe this new time is actually very much in line with the very, very old time in a Greenlandic or Arctic sense."

The "new" circular economy:
â€¢ Resource efficiency
â€¢ Waste reduction
â€¢ Design for longevity
â€¢ Community-based systems

= Ancient Arctic practices.

â“ **THE TIMELESS QUESTION:**
"How do we make use of what we have in a way that's not going to restrict future generations from doing what they need to do?"

This has ALWAYS been the Arctic question.

ğŸŒ **POPULATION SCALE:**

Greenland: 0.00068% of world population
Complete Arctic: 0.05% of world population

**THE IMPLICATION:**
"We might not have the best result from trying to put our efforts into innovating new specific high-tech materials."

**THE FOCUS:**
"How do we utilize APPLICATIONS of whatever material is available."

ğŸ  **DESIGN FOR DISASSEMBLY - A PERSONAL STORY:**

Inooraq's father born 1945 in small settlement.
Family moved 1948.

Decades later, visiting birthplace:
"Dad, where's the house you were born in?"

"Well, I don't know."

Aunt in room:
**"The house, we brought it."** ğŸ¡â¡ï¸

Traditional construction = design for disassembly.

Reusable in other settings as needs change.

What we call "innovation" today.

ğŸ—ï¸ **ROBUST SOLUTIONS FOR REMOTE AREAS:**

"We are often building in remote areas where a carpenter might not be able to come by next week."

**SO:**
âœ… Important to have robust solutions
âœ… High level of detail required
âœ… People must maintain themselves

**CONTEXT VARIES ENORMOUSLY:**
â€¢ Nuuk = metropolis
â€¢ Two hours by boat into fjord = 50-person settlement

Different ways of living.
Not just climate.
Population size + infrastructure access.

ğŸ’° **RENOVATION ECONOMICS:**

**DISKO BAY HOUSING BLOCKS:**
â€¢ Stripping down to main construction
â€¢ Refurbishing for new life
â€¢ **About HALF the cost of new building**

**WHY IT MATTERS:**
"The structural parts of a building is also where you have the largest CO2, especially when it's concrete."

Keep structure = massive emissions savings.

ğŸ”„ **CATCHING UP ON MAINTENANCE:**

"We've had a lack of maintenance of a lot of our buildings. So we're trying to catch up on that."

**THE POSITIVE SHIFT:**
"The larger focus that we are seeing on maintenance and renovation and transformation is very positive."

Government + municipal levels both pushing.

ğŸ’¡ **WHAT GLOBAL BUSINESSES CAN LEARN:**

1. **Constraints = innovation drivers**
   If it works in Arctic, it works anywhere

2. **Robust design = essential everywhere**
   Supply chains increasingly fragile
   Skilled trades facing labor shortages

3. **Traditional knowledge = modern solutions**
   Don't reinvent circular economy
   Learn from those who never abandoned it

4. **Maintenance > new construction**
   Economic + environmental + social case clear

5. **Population scale doesn't limit impact**
   0.00068% of world, but leading circular thinking

ğŸŒŸ **THE META-LESSON:**

What industrialization dismissed as "primitive" is now recognized as:
â€¢ More durable
â€¢ More maintainable
â€¢ More sustainable
â€¢ More culturally meaningful
â€¢ More economically viable

Circular economy isn't innovation.

It's RECONNECTION.

To place. To practice. To wisdom that survived millennia.

Because it worked.

â†’ Integrated principles into LEADER funding (EU rural development)

ğŸ”ï¸ **ARCTIC CONSTRUCTION WISDOM**

"The words that come to mind when people describe this new time is actually very much in line with the very, very old time in a Greenlandic or Arctic sense."
â€” Inooraq Brandt

Circular economy = ancient Arctic practices!

Key principles:
â†’ Robust solutions (carpenter won't come by next week)
â†’ Design for disassembly (Inooraq's father's house was moved!)
â†’ Maintenance-first thinking
â†’ Use applications of available materials, not high-tech innovation
â†’ "As a WIC, we can use almost anything"â€”survival depends on it

Disko Bay renovation example: Strip to main construction, refurbish = ~50% cost of new building

Greenland population: 0.00068% of world
But: leading circular thinking that others can learn from!

ğŸ“Š **NORDIC LCA COLLABORATION**

"Within five years, the Nordic countries have this vision of being the most sustainable and integrated region in the world."
â€” Helle Redder Momsen

2030 = 5 years away!

LCA (Life Cycle Assessment) requirements spreading:
â†’ Sweden: First to mandate
â†’ Norway: Shortly after
â†’ Denmark 2023: Calculate + limit values
â†’ Iceland Sept 2024: Joined
â†’ Finland 2026: Coming
â†’ EU 2028: Buildings >1,000 sqm
â†’ EU 2030: All countries plan to 2050

GAME-CHANGER: Reused products in LCA = SET TO ZERO
Not real number (transport/processing has emissions), but provides political push!

Three work packages: Climate/LCA (Iceland), Circularity (Denmark), EU coordination (Sweden)

Policy measures catalogue being developed for all Nordic countries.

Educational program: 6 Nordic languages + English, freely available online!

ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡± **GREENLAND: TRUST-BASED STRATEGY**

"We must succeed together. We're not gonna put in legislation. We should be able to do this together and agree."
â€” Embla KristjÃ¡nsdÃ³ttir

National sustainability strategy (2024) for construction sector:
â†’ Small industry with strong community
â†’ Lot of trust between all working in industry
â†’ Collective agreement, not top-down mandates
â†’ Holistic approach across entire sector

6 goals (intentionally limited): "Should be goals we can actually meet"

7 concrete initiatives including:
â†’ National DGNB system (government will use standard but not get certification)
â†’ Shared LCA methodology
â†’ Council for Sustainability
â†’ CO2 action plan

Challenge: "We don't have any data at the moment."
Answer: Start somewhere, build baseline during implementation.

Honesty about challenges builds credibility!

---

ğŸ’¡ **KEY TAKEAWAYS:**

âœ… "The language of this structure is economy, is numbers." Learn to speak circular economic!

âœ… "The life of placeâ€”city life, village life, neighborhood lifeâ€”is also the life of our planet."

âœ… Triangulate: Place + Approach + Topic = Concrete value proposition

âœ… Trust must be embedded in transparent structures

âœ… Culture shapes behavior more than regulation

âœ… Renovation: 50% cost, massive CO2 savings

âœ… Circular procurement = market shaping, not just purchasing

âœ… Urban-rural knowledge flows = bidirectional (both have wisdom to share)

âœ… Scale-appropriate solutions (capital cities to 50-person settlements)

âœ… Traditional knowledge + contemporary systems = circular future

---

ğŸŒŸ **THE BIG PICTURE:**

The session demonstrated that circular cities are not built by centralized mandates or universal blueprints.

They emerge from place-based approaches that:
â†’ Honor local context
â†’ Respect traditional knowledge
â†’ Build community trust
â†’ Connect to global systems
â†’ Speak economic language
â†’ Prioritize renovation
â†’ Leverage procurement
â†’ Enable cooperation

From place to planet, one project at a time, one building at a time, one community at a time, one memorandum at a time, one procurement at a time.

This is how circular cities are built.

---

Thank you to everyone in Nuuk and online! ğŸ™

title: How Can Your City Become Circular? Share Your Ideas!
content:
ğŸ™ï¸ HOW CAN YOUR CITY BECOME CIRCULAR?

We just wrapped Session 5 at Nordic Circular Summit 2025 with incredible examples from Riga, Cesis, Oslo, and Greenland! ğŸŒ

Now we want to hear from YOU! ğŸ’¬

---

ğŸ¤” **QUESTIONS FOR THE COMMUNITY:**

1ï¸âƒ£ **RENOVATION vs. NEW CONSTRUCTION**

Greenland is renovating housing blocks at ~50% the cost of building new, with massive CO2 savings.

Does your city prioritize renovation? What are the barriers? What would help?

2ï¸âƒ£ **CIRCULAR PROCUREMENT**

Riga embeds circular criteria in ALL procurement. Cesis is transforming school food procurement to local, organic.

What could your city/region do with procurement power? Share ideas!

3ï¸âƒ£ **TRUST-BASED vs. REGULATION-BASED**

Greenland chose collective agreement over mandatory legislation, relying on community trust.

Which approach works better in your context? Why?

4ï¸âƒ£ **URBAN RESOURCE CENTERS**

Riga's repair facility + community center model is spreading.

Does your city have something similar? Would you use one? What should it include?

5ï¸âƒ£ **BIOREGION CONCEPT**

Cesis created the first Baltic bioregion: voluntary agreement among municipalities, farmers, businesses, NGOs to manage resources sustainably.

Could this work in your region? What would be the biggest challenge?

6ï¸âƒ£ **TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE**

Arctic communities practiced circular economy for millennia (necessity, not trend).

What traditional circular practices exist in YOUR community that have been forgotten?

---

ğŸ’¡ **KEY INSIGHTS TO CONSIDER:**

âœ… "The most important thing you have to build when you build places is trust." â€” Einar Kleppe Holthe

âœ… "We cannot excel in every area being all alone. By working together, small regions can achieve more." â€” Inese Suija-Markova

âœ… "The words that come to mind when people describe this new time is actually very much in line with the very, very old time in a Greenlandic sense." â€” Inooraq Brandt

âœ… "Within five years, the Nordic countries have this vision of being the most sustainable and integrated region in the world." â€” Helle Redder Momsen

---

ğŸŒŸ **WHAT WE LEARNED:**

â†’ Circular cities need ECONOMIC language (numbers that describe nature, human, societal, market values)
â†’ Retrofit first = economic opportunity, not just environmental
â†’ Circular procurement = enormous municipal leverage
â†’ Trust + community = foundation for all good places
â†’ Place-based approaches > universal blueprints
â†’ Traditional knowledge = modern circular solutions
â†’ Urban-rural knowledge flows = bidirectional
â†’ Scale-appropriate (capital cities to 50-person settlements)

---

ğŸ’¬ **SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS:**

Comment below with:
â€¢ What your city/region is doing (or could do)
â€¢ Barriers you're facing
â€¢ Traditional practices that should return
â€¢ Creative ideas for circular urban development
â€¢ Questions about any of the examples shared

Let's learn from each other! ğŸ¤

The transition to circular cities happens through community dialogue, knowledge sharing, and collective action.

Your voice matters. Your experience matters. Your place matters.

Because as we learned today:
"The life of placeâ€”city life, village life, neighborhood lifeâ€”is also the life of our planet."

From place to planet. Together. ğŸŒğŸ’š

title: Practitioner Guide: 10 Actions Your City Can Take Today
content:
ğŸ“‹ PRACTITIONER GUIDE: 10 Actions Your City Can Take Today

Based on Session 5 at Nordic Circular Summit 2025 ğŸŒ

From Riga, Cesis, Oslo, and Greenlandâ€”here are CONCRETE, ACTIONABLE steps for municipal leaders, urban planners, and circular economy practitioners:

---

1ï¸âƒ£ **EMBED CIRCULAR CRITERIA IN ALL PROCUREMENT** ğŸ“‹

âœ… What Riga did: Developed circular construction guidelines with construction community
âœ… What it means: Every procurement document includes circular requirements from the start
âœ… Impact: Shapes what suppliers offer, drives market transformation
âœ… How to start: Convene working group with procurement team + construction/food/service sectors

ğŸ”— No additional budget requiredâ€”just change procurement templates.

---

2ï¸âƒ£ **CREATE INTERNAL MATERIAL BANKS** ğŸ›ï¸

âœ… What Riga is doing: Departments share assets and inventory within municipality
âœ… What it means: Internal circular economy reduces redundant purchasing
âœ… Impact: Cost savings + demonstrate circularity in practice
âœ… How to start: Survey what each department owns, identify shareable assets, create simple booking system

ğŸ”— Start with one asset category (e.g., furniture, equipment).

---

3ï¸âƒ£ **CONDUCT PRE-STUDIES BEFORE MAJOR TRANSFORMATIONS** ğŸ”

âœ… What Riga/Oslo do: Pre-study before transforming buildings using circular principles
âœ… What it means: Document available materials within existing buildings
âœ… Impact: Inform procurement with circular criteria, maximize material reuse
âœ… How to start: Pilot with one building scheduled for renovation/transformation

ğŸ”— Pre-studies save money by identifying reuse opportunities early.

---

4ï¸âƒ£ **PRIORITIZE RENOVATION OVER NEW CONSTRUCTION** ğŸ—ï¸

âœ… What Greenland proves: Renovation = ~50% cost of new + massive CO2 savings
âœ… What London did: 2020 regulatory requirement to retrofit buildings first
âœ… Impact: Economic + environmental + social + cultural value
âœ… How to start: Audit existing building stock, identify candidates for renovation, develop business case

ğŸ”— Structural parts = largest CO2 (especially concrete). Keep them!

---

5ï¸âƒ£ **ESTABLISH URBAN RESOURCE CENTERS** ğŸ”§

âœ… What Riga created: Repair facility + community center
âœ… What it means: Circular design from beginning, repair guidance, community hub
âœ… Impact: EU good practice database case, citizen engagement, skill building
âœ… How to start: Identify available space, partner with repair cafes/NGOs, design for multiple uses

ğŸ”— Involve design students (competitions build engagement).

---

6ï¸âƒ£ **TRANSFORM FOOD PROCUREMENT TO LOCAL/ORGANIC** ğŸ¥—

âœ… What Cesis is doing: Schools/kindergartens procurement = local, organic ingredients
âœ… What it means: Replace anonymous supply chains with known producers
âœ… Impact: Reduced emissions + healthier food + local economic value
âœ… How to start: Pilot with one school, work toward organic certification

ğŸ”— First organically certified school kitchen in Latvia coming from this!

---

7ï¸âƒ£ **CREATE MEMORANDUM OF GOODWILL FOR YOUR REGION** ğŸ“œ

âœ… What Cesis did: 1 year to craft, 13 institutions signed (public, private, NGO, academic)
âœ… What it means: Social contract, voluntary agreement on shared values
âœ… Impact: Strategic alliance for sustainable resource management
âœ… How to start: Convene stakeholders, identify shared values, draft principles together

ğŸ”— Take time to get every word right. Ownership = commitment.

---

8ï¸âƒ£ **INTEGRATE CIRCULAR PRINCIPLES INTO EXISTING FUNDING** ğŸ’°

âœ… What Cesis achieved: Integrated bioregion principles into LEADER program (EU rural funding)
âœ… What it means: Mainstream circular criteria into funding strategies
âœ… Impact: "Great success"â€”every funding decision considers circularity
âœ… How to start: Identify existing funding programs, work with administrators to add circular criteria

ğŸ”— Don't create new fundingâ€”embed in what exists.

---

9ï¸âƒ£ **ESTABLISH COUNCIL/FORUM FOR SECTOR DIALOGUE** ğŸ—£ï¸

âœ… What Greenland did: Council for Sustainability within construction sector
âœ… What Latvia did: First Circular Economy Forum (108 speakers, 34 sessions!)
âœ… What it means: Regular dialogue, cooperation, knowledge sharing
âœ… Impact: Build trust, share practices, solve challenges collectively
âœ… How to start: Annual forum or quarterly council meetings

ğŸ”— People WANT to share circular economy storiesâ€”provide the platform.

---
ğŸ”Ÿ **DEVELOP SHARED FRAMEWORK WITHOUT MANDATORY LEGISLATION** ğŸ¤

âœ… What Greenland chose: Trust-based strategy, collective agreement
âœ… What it means: "We should be able to do this together and agree"
âœ… Impact: Faster movement in small, trusted communities
âœ… How to start: Assess if your context has strong community trust, create dialogue-based approach
âœ… When it works: Small industries, strong relationships, shared culture

ğŸ”— Not every context suits thisâ€”but where trust exists, leverage it!

---

ğŸ“Š **MEASURING SUCCESS:**

Track:
â€¢ % of procurement with circular criteria
â€¢ Cost savings from renovation vs. new construction
â€¢ # of urban resource center users
â€¢ % local/organic food in public institutions
â€¢ # of material bank transactions
â€¢ Forum/council participation rates
â€¢ CO2 reductions (when data available)

Greenland's honesty: "We don't have any data at the moment."
â†’ Start somewhere, build baseline during implementation.

---

ğŸ’¬ **KEY PRINCIPLES UNDERLYING ALL ACTIONS:**

âœ… **Trust as foundation**: "If you don't have trust, you don't manage to create any good place."

âœ… **Economic language**: Use numbers to describe nature, human, societal, market values

âœ… **Place-based approach**: Context mattersâ€”adapt, don't copy

âœ… **Triangulate**: Place + Approach + Topic = Concrete value proposition

âœ… **Culture shapes behavior**: Communication and cultural understanding = key

âœ… **Procurement = leverage**: Market shaping, not just purchasing

âœ… **Urban-rural symbiosis**: Bidirectional knowledge flows

âœ… **Traditional knowledge**: Learn from those who never abandoned circular practices

---

ğŸ¯ **2030 VISION:**

"Within five years, the Nordic countries have this vision of being the most sustainable and integrated region in the world."
â€” Helle Redder Momsen, Nordic Sustainable Construction

5 years = 2030.

The tools exist.
The examples exist.
The economic case exists.

Question: execution.

And that depends on trust.

---

ğŸŒŸ **START WHERE YOU ARE:**

â†’ Choose 1-3 actions that fit your context
â†’ Build on existing trust and relationships
â†’ Start small, demonstrate success, scale up
â†’ Share your learnings with others
â†’ Connect to broader networks (Nordic, EU, global)

From place to planet, one action at a time. ğŸŒğŸ’š
